author: jerenkrantz
msg: Add serf_spider program that might start to work with swish-e.

author: jerenkrantz
msg: Fix build system to work with new filters and buckets directories.
(Bump to serf 0.0.5.)

author: jerenkrantz
msg: Add deflate support to serf.  (Bump to serf 0.0.4 due to new feature.)
- Add autoconf code to detect and verify zlib
- Implement serf_deflate_read function
- Conditionally export serf_deflate_* and serf_ssl_* depending upon if we
have the required libraries.
- Add deflate filters to serf_get.
Strongly derived from: Apache HTTP Server 2.0's mod_deflate

author: jerenkrantz
msg: Add SSL support to Serf.  (This feature merits bump to 0.0.3 of serf)
Remember to use --enable-ssl to turn this on.
- Switch from using serf_config.h to serf_auto_config.h for autoheader
header.  (This allows us to have serf_config.h be substituted by
autoconf and serf_auto_config.h have the autoheader defines.)
- Fix up autoconf tests related to SSL detection
- Add Darwin default location to SSL certs
- Add serf_auto_config.h to .cvsignore in include/
- Add serf_filter_socket.c which contains the basic read/write socket filters.
- Since serf_filter_read is now available, remove hack in serf_request.c
that inserted the socket for us.
- Add endpoint-specific context to serf_connection_t.
(Need some way to get the read and write filters to share a context!)
- Add SSL socket bucket (serf_bucket_ssl.c)
- Add SSL filter code (serf_filter_ssl.c)
- Remove socket_write_full from serf_get as that is now serf_socket_write
- Add conditional logic in serf_get to use the SSL filters if using an
https URL.

author: jerenkrantz
msg: Introduce response filters that are able to process HTTP/1.1 responses.
This introduces several 'base' filters:
- HTTP Status code filter
- HTTP header filter
- HTTP (de)chunking filter
A rough, non-completed implementation of deflate filters are also present.
(I know what would need to be done, but the code is a bit much right now
for that.)
Some rework has also been done to serf_get to add these new filters and
streamline the code a little bit.  (Note the #defines which control its
verbosity.)
Since Serf is now conditionally HTTP/1.1-compliant, bump the version up to
